clinical_study.brief_title: Family Strength Oriented Therapeutic Conversation for Parents of Adolescent With ADHD: Pilot Study
clinical_study.official_title: Family Strength Oriented Therapeutic Conversation for Parents of 13-17 Years Old Adolescent With Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, Outpatient at the Children's and Adolescent Psychiatric Unit. Pilot Study.

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of the study is to see the benefits of Family Strength Oriented Therapeutic Conversation for parents of adolescent with ADHD at the children's and adolescent psychiatric outpatient national unit.
In the study, 13-17 year olds adolescents diagnosed with ADHD. From this group, 10 adolescent are chosen by hand and their parents are divided. The intervention consists of three groups with 4-10 parents in group and two parents interviews.
Method of quasi experimental study are used. Parents and adolescents respond to the questionnaire initially for the intervention and in the end of the intervention. Used questionnaires will be used, all of which have good legitimacy and confidentiality. The intervention will be tested by a repeat analysis of variance, ANOVA and with a paired t-test The ideology of the study, on the one hand, is based on the evidence-based guidance of adolescents with ADHD. On the other hand, the Calgary family initiative and treatment model, in addition to the weakness of the attitude model, is based on a systematic and communicative approach. The benefit study is evaluated by parents and adolescents themselves.
The result can provide clues as to whether / what benefits from the intervention. An important finding for continued development of family-oriented nursing care based on critical knowledge with the aim of improving adolescent quality of life with ADHD

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of this pilot study was to evaluate the feasibilty of a Family Strength Oriented Therapeutic Conversation based on the Cagary Family Assessment model, the Cagary Family Intervention model, and the Illness Beliefs model. Barkley´s clinical guidelines were also used as a theoretical framework.

primary_outcome.description: Caregivers answered a questionnaire regarding group caregiving sessions and individual caregiving sessions regarding education, conversation, tasks, and support. Answers to the questionnaire are either given as yes/no, open answers or a 5-point scale with a scoring range from 1 to 5; a higher score indicates a more positive experience.

The CHIP measures parental coping patterns when parents have a child who is seriously and/or chronically ill. The CHIP comprises three subscales (dimensions) measuring three different coping patterns: a) maintaining family integration, co-operation, and an optimistic definition of the situation; b) maintaining social support, self-esteem, and psychological stability; and c) understanding the healthcare situation through communication with other parents and consultation with the healthcare team. The questionnaire is a 5-point scale; higher scores indicate more coping ability.

GWBS is an 18-item instrument measuring positive and negative feelings: anxiety, depression, general health, positive well-being, self-control and vitality. The first 14 questions are 6-point scale (1=all of the time, 6=none of the time) and questions 15-18 are 1-10-point rating scales defined by adjectives feeling at each end.

The Family Impact Module is an instrument of 37 items that measures family's quality of life. Eight subscales of parents functioning that compact physical, emotional, social, cognitive, communications, worrying, daily activity and relationships in the family. It is scale with a scoring range from 0 to 4; a higher score indicates a better quality of life.

It is a 4-point scale format ranging from strongly agree to strongly disagree. Higher scores indicate higher self-esteem of positive thinking for building resilience.
